questions.text: A 34-year-old man comes to the physician for a 2-month history of an itchy rash on his forearm. He feels well otherwise and has not had any fever or chills. He returned from an archaeological expedition to Guatemala 4 months ago. Skin examination shows a solitary, round, pink-colored plaque with central ulceration on the right wrist. There is right axillary lymphadenopathy. A photomicrograph of a biopsy specimen from the lesion is shown. Which of the following is the most likely causal organism?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Treponema pallidum causes syphilis, a sexually transmitted disease. Primary syphilis classically manifests with a painless chancre, which starts out as a single raised papule on the genitals and evolves into an ulcer with indurated borders and is accompanied by inguinal lymphadenopathy. While this patient also has a solitary, ulcerated lesion with regional lymphadenopathy, the location of the lesion and skin biopsy with amastigotes is not consistent with primary syphilis.

Dermatologic findings in secondary syphilis include a diffuse maculopapular rash affecting the palms and soles or condyloma lata.
Image Description:

A superficial ulcer with indurated borders is visible on the glans penis.

This finding is consistent with primary syphilis.

B) INCORRECT:

Trichophyton rubrum is a dermatophyte that causes the fungal skin infection tinea. The disease can affect various areas of the body, including the feet (tinea pedis), nails (tinea unguium), scalp (tinea capitis), torso (tinea corporis) and groin (tinea cruris). Lesions present as erythematous, circular, pruritic plaques with central clearing. Amastigotes would not be seen on biopsy of the skin lesions.
Image Description:

Four round, erythematous plaques with central clearing and raised, scaly borders are visible on this patient's arm.

C) INCORRECT:

Sarcoptes scabiei causes scabies, a highly contagious skin infection that spreads via direct physical contact. The disease manifests as reddish, pruritic papules and vesicles on the wrists and intertriginous regions. Thin burrow tracks are also commonly observed. This patient's isolated, non-healing, ulcerated lesion and amastigotes on skin biopsy are not consistent with scabies.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a human itch mite (Sarcoptes scabiei var. hominis)

Sarcoptes scabiei var. hominis, the mite that causes scabies, has a round body and four pairs of legs (green overlay): The front legs end in suckers, while the hind legs end in long bristles. Between the medial front legs, the scabies mite has a mouthpart (red overlay) that it uses for burrowing into the host's skin. Between the medial posterior pairs of legs, the anus of the mite is visible (yellow overlay), from which the female mites lay eggs in the skin's stratum corneum.

D) INCORRECT:

Trypanosoma brucei is a protozoan transmitted via the bite of the tsetse fly and is the causative agent in African sleeping sickness. The disease is characterized by recurrent fever, lymphadenopathy, somnolence, and coma, none of which are seen in this patient. Peripheral blood smear of infected patients would show trypomastigotes, the infective form of the parasite, but amastigotes on skin biopsy would not be seen.

E) INCORRECT:

Ancylostoma duodenale causes hookworm infection. The disease manifests after the parasite penetrates intact skin, usually via the feet while walking barefoot. The cutaneous phase involves an itchy maculopapular eruption at the site of larval penetration. Occasionally, serpiginous tracks caused by larval migration can be seen (cutaneous larva migrans). This patient has not reported that his lesion is associated with pruritus and the lesion has evolved over a longer period of time, as opposed to the acute onset of cutaneous Ancylostoma infection. Moreover, a biopsy showing amastigotes is not consistent with this diagnosis.

F) INCORRECT:

Rickettsia rickettsii is transmitted via tick bite and causes rocky mountain spotted fever. Rickettsia rickettsii is endemic to the southern Atlantic states in the US and typically causes a macular rash that originates at the wrists and ankles before spreading to the trunk and extremities; other signs may include fever, headache, myalgia, conjunctivitis, and hepatosplenomegaly. This patient's recent travel to Guatemala, rash distribution, and amastigotes on skin biopsy suggest infection with a different pathogen.
Image Description:

Multiple, partly confluent, macules are visible on this patient's forearm.

This rash is suggestive of Rocky Mountain spotted fever (RMSF), a tick-borne disease caused by Rickettsia rickettsii bacteria. The distal extremities are usually affected first; the rash then spreads toward the proximal extremities and the trunk (the face, however, is usually spared).

G) INCORRECT:

Borrelia burgdorferi causes Lyme disease, a tick-borne infection that is most common in the Northeastern United States. Infection first manifests as a localized rash known as erythema migrans. A non-healing, ulcerated lesion and amastigotes on skin biopsy are not consistent with Lyme disease.
Image Description:

A circular erythematous rash with a central clearing (“bulls-eye” rash) is visible on the upper back.

Erythema migrans is typically seen in the early localized stage of Lyme disease.

H) CORRECT:

Leishmania braziliensis is the most likely causal organism in a patient with a history of recent travel to Guatemala who presents with a chronic skin ulcer and has a biopsy showing macrophages with amastigotes. L. braziliensis is transmitted to humans via infected sandflies and usually begins as a reddish papule around the sandfly bite that then enlarges into a nodule, oftentimes with central ulceration. Definitive diagnosis of cutaneous leishmaniasis requires detection of the pathogen in a skin biopsy, as seen here. Leishmaniasis is treated with miltefosine, stibogluconate, or a single dose of amphotericin B.
Image Description:

A well-demarcated, open, ulcerated wound with overlying purulent exudate is visible on the lateral aspect of the right ankle.

This is the characteristic appearance of cutaneous leishmaniasis.
questions.hint: The photograph shows macrophages with cytoplasmic amastigotes. The causal organism is transmitted by phlebotomine sand flies.

questions.text: A 26-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 3-week history of malaise and recurrent fever. He has also had a 4.5-kg (10-lb) weight loss over the past 3 months. He came back from his honeymoon in Kenya 6 months ago. He appears ill. His temperature is 39.0°C (102.2°F). He is alert and oriented to person, time, and place. Physical examination shows generalized lymphadenopathy and hepatosplenomegaly. Laboratory studies show a hemoglobin concentration of 9.1 g/dL, leukocyte count of 2,900/mm3, and platelet count of 108,000/mm3. Which of the following is the most likely vector of this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The tsetse fly is the vector for African trypanosomiasis (sleeping sickness), a disease caused by the parasite Trypanosoma brucei. The first stage of this disease can manifest with fever, malaise, weight loss, lymphadenopathy, and anemia. However, it is typically preceded by a trypanosomal chancre that develops at the bite site within 2 weeks of the bite, which is not seen in this patient. Manifestations of the second stage of this disease include headache, behavioral changes, daytime somnolence, ataxia, and coma, none of which is seen in this patient. This patient's presentation is more consistent with visceral leishmaniasis, for which the tsetse fly is not the vector.

B) CORRECT:

Visceral leishmaniasis, a parasitic disease caused by protozoans of the Leishmania genus, is transmitted by infected phlebotomine sand flies. Most leishmaniasis infections are asymptomatic. However, they can cause fever, malaise, weight loss, lymphadenopathy, hepatosplenomegaly, and pancytopenia, as seen in this patient. Cutaneous leishmaniasis is also a possible manifestation. The diagnosis of leishmaniasis is confirmed with microscopic visualization of macrophages containing amastigotes in blood smears and/or tissue. Amphotericin B is the treatment of choice.

C) INCORRECT:

Infected specific freshwater snails are the vector for schistosomiasis, a parasitic disease caused by Schistosoma species. These parasites are transmitted when humans come in contact with water contaminated by cercaria from the snails. Acute schistosomiasis syndrome can manifest with fever and fatigue. However, it does not manifest with lymphadenopathy or pancytopenia. In addition, this patient does not have other typical findings of schistosomiasis, including rash, cough, myalgia, and angioedema. Schistosomiasis is common in East Africa; however, the incubation period is 3–8 weeks; this patient developed symptoms 6 months after traveling. His presentation is more consistent with visceral leishmaniasis, for which freshwater snails are not the vector.

D) INCORRECT:

The female Anopheles mosquito is the vector for malaria, a potentially life‑threatening tropical disease caused by Plasmodium parasites. Malaria can manifest with recurrent fever, malaise, hepatosplenomegaly, anemia, and thrombocytopenia. However, malaria is also associated with nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, and diarrhea, which are not seen in this patient. In addition, most cases of malaria occur in West and Central Africa, rather than Kenya, which is in East Africa. Moreover, the incubation period for malaria is 7–42 days; this patient developed symptoms 6 months after traveling. This patient's presentation is more consistent with a diagnosis of visceral leishmaniasis, for which the Anopheles mosquito is not the vector.
Image Description:

A female Anopheles mosquito (Anopheles gambiae) sucking blood from the photographer's hand using its proboscis. The mosquito's abdomen is already filled and expanded to the extent that one drop of blood is directly excreted. At the start of the blood meal, the mosquito injects saliva that contains anticoagulation agents and, in some cases, sporozoites (infectious form of the malaria parasite).

E) INCORRECT:

Triatomine bugs are the vector for Chagas disease, a disease caused by the parasite Trypanosoma cruzi. Chagas disease causes fever, malaise, lymphadenopathy, and hepatosplenomegaly. However, this patient does not have other typical findings of Chagas disease, including edema of the bite site, eyelids, and/or periocular tissue. In addition, Chagas disease is endemic to Central and South America, not Kenya. This patient's presentation is more consistent with visceral leishmaniasis, for which the triatomine bug is not the vector.
Image Description:

Reduviid bug of the species Triatoma infestans (important vector of Chagas disease)

The reduviid bug usually bites individuals in their sleep and sheds infectious feces next to the bite site. The trypanosomes present in the feces can enter the body when the bitten individual scratches the bite site. Since the reduviid bug tends to bite the face, it is also called the “kissing bug.”
questions.hint: The combination of spiking fevers, malaise, weight loss, lymphadenopathy, hepatosplenomegaly, and pancytopenia in a patient who came back from East Africa 6 months ago suggests a diagnosis of visceral leishmaniasis.

questions.text: A 31-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 2-month history of a lesion in his left nostril. The lesion has rapidly increased in size during this time and now also involves the nasal septum. Two years ago, he had a nodular lesion with central ulceration on the dorsum of his left hand that resolved spontaneously. The patient emigrated from Bolivia 1 year ago; he currently lives in California and works as a carpenter. He has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. He does not smoke, drink alcohol, or use illicit drugs. His vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows left submandibular lymphadenopathy. A photograph of the lesion on his nose is shown. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely causal organism?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Trypanosoma brucei, which is transmitted by the tsetse fly, causes African trypanosomiasis. Following a tsetse fly bite, an ulcerating skin nodule (trypanosomal chancre) with regional lymphadenopathy would develop at the site of T. brucei inoculation, and this primary lesion would resolve spontaneously within 1–2 weeks. However, nasal ulceration is not consistent with this condition. Instead, constitutional symptoms (e.g., fever, malaise, weight loss) and neurological symptoms (e.g., personality changes, altered sleep-wake cycle, ataxia, delayed hyperesthesia) would be expected. Furthermore, African trypanosomiasis is endemic in sub-Saharan Africa, not South America, where this patient emigrated from.
Image Description:

An ulcerating swelling with an erythematous base is visible on this patient's neck.

B) CORRECT:

Cutaneous leishmaniasis (CL) manifests as an ulcerating skin lesion at the site of a sandfly bite; the lesion gradually resolves without treatment. However, certain species of Leishmania (L. braziliensis, L. guyanensis, L. panamensis) can cause mucosal leishmaniasis (ML) months to years after CL resolves. The nasopharynx is typically affected in ML, which can result in nasal blockage, mucosal bleeding, and/or septal destruction. Cervical lymphadenopathy can also occur. South America (especially Bolivia, Peru, and Brazil), where the patient emigrated from, is an endemic region for Leishmania species that cause ML. ML warrants systemic therapy using amphotericin B, miltefosine, or sodium stibogluconate.

Visceral leishmaniasis, a more severe form of leishmaniasis, is primarily caused by Leishmania donovani and Leishmania infantum, both of which are also transmitted via sand flies. This form of leishmaniasis is also known as “kala-azar” (black fever in Hindi).
Image Description:

A well-demarcated, open, ulcerated wound with overlying purulent exudate is visible on the lateral aspect of the right ankle.

This is the characteristic appearance of cutaneous leishmaniasis.

C) INCORRECT:

Histoplasma capsulatum infection (histoplasmosis) can manifest with lymphadenopathy and skin nodules in the case of disseminated disease. However, the lesions of histoplasmosis do not resolve spontaneously, and ulcerations within the skin nodules or nasal ulcerations are uncommon. Palatal or lingual ulcers would be expected instead. Also, most patients with histoplasmosis are typically immunocompromised and present with fever, fatigue, weight loss, pulmonary symptoms (e.g., cough), and/or hepatosplenomegaly. Moreover, histoplasmosis is commonly transmitted via exposure to bird and bat droppings commonly found along the river valleys of Mississippi, not in California, where this patient lives.
Image Description:

(Map based on data from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, 2015)

D) INCORRECT:

Mycobacterium leprae infection (leprosy) can manifest with ulceration of the nasal mucosa and ulcerating skin nodules. Leprosy is also endemic in tropical regions in South America as well as South and South-east Asia. However, leprosy typically causes multiple nodules, whereas this patient had a single nodule. Furthermore, this patient lacks other typical findings of leprosy such as hypopigmented patches or plaques, nerve thickening, and neuropathy.
Image Description:

45-year-old woman with a five-year history of facial appearance changes and paresthesia of both hands and feet

The skin of the face is thickened and furrowed, with multiple areas of nodular lesions coalescing into plaques. The hair of the eyebrows has been lost (madarosis), and there is a saddle nose deformity.

Leonine facies (so termed after the ostensible resemblance to a lion's face) is characteristic of lepromatous leprosy, as seen here, and Paget disease of bone, but can also occur various other conditions, e.g., mycosis fungoides, leishmaniasis, or sarcoidosis.

E) INCORRECT:

Rhizopus oryzae infection (mucormycosis) can manifest with a skin lesion due to local inoculation (cutaneous mucormycosis) and ulceration of the nasal mucosa in the case of rhino-orbital-cerebral mucormycosis (ROCM). However, the lesions of mucormycosis do not resolve spontaneously, and ROCM would be associated with features of necrotizing rhinosinusitis (e.g., fever, severe headache, cranial nerve palsies, periorbital cellulitis). Also, patients with mucormycosis typically have uncontrolled diabetes mellitus or immunosuppression.
Image Description:

Bilateral edema of the eyelid and purulent exudation from both eyes is visible. There are spotted areas of necrotic eschar, especially close to the inner canthus of the right eye, on the right eyelid, and on the nose.

These findings, especially in an immunocompromised patient, suggest Mucorales infection.
questions.hint: The image shows destruction of the nasal mucosa with ulcerations extending to the nasal septum and skin. The causal organism is transmitted by phlebotomine sand flies.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man presents to the emergency department with a 3-week history of daily fevers, progressive fatigue, and weight loss. He returned from visiting family in rural India 4 months ago. Physical examination reveals fever, marked hepatosplenomegaly, and darkened skin on the palms and soles. Laboratory studies show hemoglobin 8.2 g/dL, white blood cell count 2,100/μL, and platelet count 78,000/μL. Blood cultures are pending. After discussing the case with an infectious disease specialist, which of the following is the most appropriate empiric treatment to initiate while awaiting confirmatory diagnostic studies?

choices.text: Supportive care only pending diagnostic confirmation

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Fluconazole is an azole antifungal that can be used as systemic therapy for cutaneous leishmaniasis but is not the preferred treatment for visceral leishmaniasis. This patient's presentation with fever, hepatosplenomegaly, and pancytopenia is consistent with visceral rather than cutaneous disease.

B) CORRECT:

Correct – Liposomal amphotericin B is the preferred systemic therapy for visceral leishmaniasis in immunocompetent patients. This patient's presentation with spiking fevers, hepatosplenomegaly, pancytopenia, and travel history to an endemic region (India) is highly suggestive of visceral leishmaniasis (kala-azar).

C) INCORRECT:

Ivermectin is an antiparasitic medication effective against various helminthic and ectoparasitic infections but generally is not used for treating leishmaniasis.

D) INCORRECT:

Delaying treatment while awaiting diagnostic confirmation is inappropriate for suspected visceral leishmaniasis given its high mortality without treatment. All patients with clinical and laboratory findings consistent with visceral leishmaniasis should receive systemic therapy.

E) INCORRECT:

Doxycycline is used for various rickettsial and tick-borne diseases that can cause fever, but is not generally used for treatment of leishmaniasis.

questions.text: A 32-year-old patient with diabetes presents with a 4-week history of a painless 3.8-cm lesion on the lateral ankle (shown in photograph) following a 2-month trip to Peru. Regional lymphadenopathy is present. The patient remains afebrile with no mucosal involvement. Tissue sampling from the lesion border has been obtained. Which factor most strongly indicates the need for systemic rather than local therapy?

choices.text: Absence of pain suggesting deep infiltration

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Correct -- Diabetes mellitus compromises immune function, placing this patient at risk for severe or disseminated cutaneous leishmaniasis. Systemic rather than local therapy is recommended to prevent treatment failure and disease progression.

B) INCORRECT:

Central ulceration is a characteristic feature of localized cutaneous leishmaniasis and represents normal disease progression rather than an indication for systemic therapy. The lesions typically begin as reddish macules or papules that increase in size and develop central ulceration over time.

C) INCORRECT:

Regional lymphadenopathy is a common finding in localized cutaneous leishmaniasis and does not independently indicate the need for systemic therapy.

D) INCORRECT:

The duration of symptoms alone does not determine treatment approach. Cutaneous leishmaniasis lesions can persist for months to years and may heal spontaneously.

E) INCORRECT:

Cutaneous leishmaniasis characteristically manifests with painless lesions, making the absence of pain an expected finding rather than an indication for systemic therapy.
